comment: Allright, founded a new section, which is just an early scratch but works now. Alter what ye wish, added NN-tags for Wisdom an' added some info, plus stocked the links a bit.

diff.*:
Line 1: Line 1:   +  
{{merge|philosophy}}
 
{{merge|philosophy}}
  +  
Wisdom is that state that enables us to look at a decision, a thought, or an act, in the same way across time, moods, and other factors.
 
Wisdom is that state that enables us to look at a decision, a thought, or an act, in the same way across time, moods, and other factors.
    −
In many ways, '''Wisdom''' is the ability to make correct judgments and decisions. Some think it is an intangible quality gained through [[experience]]. Yet others think it is a quality that even a child, otherwise immature, may possess independent of experience or complete knowledge. Whether or not something is '''wise''' is often determined in a pragmatic sense by its popularity, how long it has been around, and its ability to predict against future events. Wisdom is also accepted from [[cultural]], [[philosophical]] and [[religious]] sources; in this sense, wisdom is often listed along side other virtues [[Insight]], [[Knowledge]], and [[Prudence]]. Some think of wisdom as foreseeing consequences and acting to maximize beneficial results.
+
In many ways, '''Wisdom''' is seen as the ability to make correct judgments and decisions. Some think it is an intangible quality gained through [[experience]]. Yet others think it is a quality that even a child, otherwise immature, may possess independent of experience or complete knowledge. Whether or not something is '''wise''' is often determined in a pragmatic sense by its popularity, how long it has been around, and its ability to predict against future events. Wisdom is also accepted from [[cultural]], [[philosophical]] and [[religious]] sources; in this sense, wisdom is often listed along side other virtues [[Insight]], [[Knowledge]], and [[Prudence]]. Some think of wisdom as foreseeing consequences and acting to maximize beneficial results.
     
Many modern authorities on government, religion and philosophical [[ethics]] say that wisdom connotes an enlightened perspective. This perspective is sometimes defined in a [[utilitarian]] way, as effective support for the long-term common [[goodness|good]].
 
Many modern authorities on government, religion and philosophical [[ethics]] say that wisdom connotes an enlightened perspective. This perspective is sometimes defined in a [[utilitarian]] way, as effective support for the long-term common [[goodness|good]].
    −
==Wisdom and philosophy==
+
==Wisdom and Philosophy==
     
A standard [[philosophy|philosophical]] definition says that wisdom consists of making the best use of available [[propositional knowledge|knowledge]]. As with all decisions, a wise decision may be made with incomplete [[information]]. The technical philosophical term for the opposite of wisdom is [[folly]].
 
A standard [[philosophy|philosophical]] definition says that wisdom consists of making the best use of available [[propositional knowledge|knowledge]]. As with all decisions, a wise decision may be made with incomplete [[information]]. The technical philosophical term for the opposite of wisdom is [[folly]].
Line 12: Line 14:  
In his ''[[Metaphysics]]'', [[Aristotle]] defines wisdom as knowledge of causes: ''why'' things exist in a particular fashion.
 
In his ''[[Metaphysics]]'', [[Aristotle]] defines wisdom as knowledge of causes: ''why'' things exist in a particular fashion.
    −
==Sources of wisdom==
+
There's similiarites and differences between philosophy and wisdom, however. Philosophy isn't necessarily wise put ponders about it, also, seeing that "philosophy" means "love of wisdom" in greek, it's related to tribute wisdom but is not necessarily forced to be wise itself. Wisdom stands alone, philosophers might often strive to be wise, however.
  +   +
==Sources of Wisdom==
     
Beyond the simple expedient of experience (Which may be considered the most difficult way to gain wisdom as through the "school of hard knocks"), there are a variety of other avenues to gaining wisdom which vary according to different philosophies. For example, [[Freethought|Freethinkers]] and others believe that wisdom may come from pure [[reason]] and perhaps experience, while others believe that it comes from [[intuition]] or [[spirituality]].
 
Beyond the simple expedient of experience (Which may be considered the most difficult way to gain wisdom as through the "school of hard knocks"), there are a variety of other avenues to gaining wisdom which vary according to different philosophies. For example, [[Freethought|Freethinkers]] and others believe that wisdom may come from pure [[reason]] and perhaps experience, while others believe that it comes from [[intuition]] or [[spirituality]].
Line 20: Line 22:  
* [[Holistic|Holists]] believe that wise people sense, work with and align themselves and others to [[life]]. In this view, wise people help others appreciate the fundamental [[interconnectedness]] of life.
 
* [[Holistic|Holists]] believe that wise people sense, work with and align themselves and others to [[life]]. In this view, wise people help others appreciate the fundamental [[interconnectedness]] of life.
    −
* Some religions hold that wisdom may be given as a gift from God.
+
* ''Some religions hold that wisdom may be given as a gift from God.''
−
In the Christian Bible, for example, there are three wise men sent by God to give the newly born Jesus three gifts.
+
In the Christian Bible, for example, there were three wise men sent by God to give the newly born Jesus three gifts. In the Koran the prophet Muahammed is chosen by Allah to represent his wisdom. Also in the Bible, it's heavily represented by the sense of justice by the lawful and wise king [[Solomon]].
    −
* The seventh verse of the first chapter of the [[Jew]]ish book of [[Book of Proverbs|Proverbs]] in the [[Old Testament]] states "Fear of God is the beginning of Wisdom" (Proverbs 1:7). The beginning of fear of God is hating evil, the ways of evil, arrogance, pride and a duplicitous mouth (Proverbs).
+
* The seventh verse of the first chapter of the [[Jew]]ish book of [[Book of Proverbs|Proverbs]] in the [[Old Testament]] states "Fear of God is the beginning of Wisdom" (Proverbs 1:7). The beginning of fear of God is hating evil, the ways of evil, arrogance, pride and a duplicitous mouth (Proverbs).
    −
* [[Confucius]] stated that wisdom can be learned by three methods: reflection (The noblest), imitation (The easiest) and experience (The bitterest).
+
* [[Confucius]] stated that wisdom can be learned by three methods: Reflection (The noblest), imitation (The easiest) and experience (The bitterest).
    −
* [[Buddha]] taught that a wise person is endowed with good bodily conduct, good verbal conduct & good mental conduct (AN3:2) and a wise person does actions that are unpleasant to do but give good results and doesn’t do actions that are pleasant to do but give bad results (AN4:115).
+
* [[Buddha]] taught that a wise person is endowed with good bodily conduct, good verbal conduct & good mental conduct (''AN3:2'') and a wise person does actions that are unpleasant to do but give good results and doesn’t do actions that are pleasant to do but give bad results (''AN4:115''). This is called called [[karma]], and is of [[Buddhism]].
  +   +
* PRACTICAL Wisdom may be described as: Knowing what to say and when to say it.--TAO
  +   +
== Culture and Wisdom ==
  +   +
The theme of Wisdom is very important in the [[Star Wars]]-series of movies, where it is subtly emphasized to know what to do prevent the dark side from winning trough manipulating folly or their nefarious and intricate attack plans, [[Yoda]] being seen as the wisest of them all.
    −
Practical WISDOM may be described as: Knowing what to say & when to say it. TAO
